STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 21, 2022
Katherine Page-Sander
Hands Across The Water
Suite 200
781 Avis Drive, Suite 200
Ann Arbor, MI 48108
RE: License #: CB810201161
Hands Across The Water
Suite 200
781 Avis Drive, Suite 200
Ann Arbor, MI 48108
Dear Ms. Page-Sander:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 9/19/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(d) Provisions for visits between siblings who are not
placed together except when there is a court determination
that visits are detrimental to either child.
One of eight foster care files was missing one monthly sibling visit.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Page 17
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following:
• Completing the MDHHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
checking it for accuracy, identifying areas needing follow-up,
and recording the outcome data.
One of eight foster care files did not have an 1105 completed for an 11/16/21 FTM.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/7/2020 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 10/29/2020.
7/27/2021 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 8/6/2021. Previously cited as 722-08C
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Page 10
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
4

One of twenty-eight PATPs had late signatures by the foster parent and mother.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/7/2020 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 10/29/2020. Previously cited as 722-08C
7/27/2021 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 8/6/2021. Previously cited as 722-08C
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 FTM reports (1105) must be entered into MiSACWIS within seven business day
of the meeting.
 When a Team Decision Meeting is held, it must be entered into MiSACWIS under
the FTM tab. The DHHS 5966 must be completed and uploaded in lieu of an
1105.
 A closing DHHS-69 must be completed and uploaded to MiSACWIS within three
days of receiving the court order to close the case.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility requested consultation regarding DHHS offices changing to paperless
systems and how that will impact closed adoption files that must be submitted to
DHHS at the 12–13-month mark, with closed foster care files. Policy office has been
contacted for clarification. Information will be shared with the agency when it is
received.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
A special evaluation was initiated on 12/14/21 due to allegations that a foster parent
hit a child. The investigation concluded the foster parent “tapped” the child’s head. A
violation of rule 9404 Behavior Management was cited, and a CAP was developed.
The foster parents completed training regarding oppositional defiance & control,
regulation through hard parenting moments, and what behavior is and how to
change it. The CAP was completed 5/23/22. However, the agency continues to
monitor the foster home and provide support as needed.
A special evaluation was initiated on 6/2/22 due to multiple allegations. A violation of
rule 9404 Behavior Management was cited due to findings the foster parent hit the
child’s wrist. A CAP was developed which included training regarding the behavior
management policy, opposition defiance & control, regulation through hard
parenting, and what behavior is and how to change it. The CAP was completed on
5

8/10/22.
Overall, the agency completed these special evaluations in compliance with
licensing rules. Findings and CAPs were found to be appropriate and consistent with
the information obtained during the evaluations.
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
A CAP, approve 8/6/21 was the result of the 7/27/21 renewal evaluation. The agency
was cited for the following contract/policy items: late case contact entry and late
treatment plan signatures. During this review, the agency has one repeat violation
regarding late PATP signatures. However, the number of late signatures has
improved significantly over the past year, which indicates the agency’s CAP has
been effectively implemented.
A CAP, approved 7/14/22, was the result of the 6/28/22 special investigation
(2022C021216). The investigation was initiated due to an allegation the agency did
not submit closed adoption files to DHHS within the required timeframe. The agency
was found in violation of policy ADM 2030. A CAP was developed to better track
closed adoption case files and their due dates to DHHS at the 12–13-month mark
after closure. CAP monitoring is ongoing.
A CAP, approved 3/16/22, was the result of the 3/2/22 special investigation
(2022C0212005).The investigation was initiated due to an allegation that a case
worker left two youth unattended in a vehicle and another worker “dragged” a child.
The agency was found in violation of rule 206, Staff qualifications. The agency
completed the CAP by reviewing the incident with staff and providing feedback,
completing several trainings, providing shadowing/coaching to the staff, and utilizing
increased supervision. There are no further concerns in this area at this time.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment (CAA) was reviewed and discussed on-site.
The CAA reported successful CAP implementation from the prior review period.
Compliance was established by increased verbal and calendar reminders, quarterly
case reviews, and time management planning for staff to complete required tasks.
Administration also participated in a Quality Improvement project with DHHS in
January 2022 regarding barriers and best practices.
The agency reported having difficulties with staffing this past year. After some staff
left the agency there was an insufficient number of applicants to interview to fill open
positions. Staff and supervisor reported feeling stressed over the increased workload
when there were vacant positions. Which resulted in the agency’s decision to
decrease the number of new cases they would accept. The agency also reported
stressors such as fingerprinting delays, court closures, barriers to permanency in
cases, COVID restrictions, limited treatment and support services in the area, and a
lack of communication and accountability from professional partners. All of these
issues have caused strain and struggle over the past year. However, the agency
6

continues to move forward, hire additional staff, and make changes as needed to
help staff through this time.
Interviews
Three agency staff were interviewed on-site, from various departments. All staff
reported the agency as being a very good place to work. Supervisors are
knowledgeable, helpful, and able to provide guidance as needed. Agency
administration is open and supportive. Although it was acknowledged this past year
was difficult in some ways, none of the staff had concerns or identified areas the
agency could improve.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
_ ____________September 20, 2022______________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 21, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
